title: SB 1.18.16 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 07-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master.

segments.key_quote: O Suta Goswami, please describe those topics of the Lord by which Maharaj Parikshit, whose intelligence was fixed, on liberation attained the lotus feet of the Lord who is the shelter of Garuda, the king of birds.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam 1.18.16, explaining that the sages of Naimisharanya are requesting Suta Goswami to speak about the topics that led Maharaj Parikshit to attain the lotus feet of the Lord, emphasizing the importance of pure intention.

segments.key_quote: The devotee of the Lord worships the transcendental form of the Lord... Whereas the impersonalist meditates upon the glaring effulgence of the bodily rays of the Lord known as the Brahmajyoti.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the difference between impersonalists and devotees, highlighting that devotees worship the transcendental form of the Lord, while impersonalists meditate on the Brahmajyoti, the Lord's bodily effulgence, and emphasizes that Parikshit Maharaj's goal was the lotus feet of the Lord, not impersonal Brahman.

segments.key_quote: Sukhdev Goswami in the beginning was an impersonalist... But later on, he was attracted by the transcendental pastimes of the Lord and thus became a devotee.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Sukadeva Goswami was initially an impersonalist but later became a devotee after being attracted to the Lord's pastimes, emphasizing the importance of hearing about the Lord and the transformative power of devotional service, referencing the Atmarama verse.

segments.key_quote: Such devotees with perfect knowledge are called Mahabhagavatas or first class devotees... There are three classes of devotees and they are called Prakrita, Madhyama and Mahabhagavata.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the three classes of devotees: Prakrita (third class), Madhyama (second class), and Mahabhagavata (first class), explaining their characteristics and how they perceive and interact with the Lord, devotees, neophytes, and non-devotees.

segments.key_quote: But the Mahabhagavata or the first class devotee sees everything in relation with the Lord and the Lord present in everyone's relation.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the unique vision of a Mahabhagavata, who sees everything connected to the Lord and the Lord present in every relationship, leading them to not distinguish between devotees and non-devotees, as they perceive everyone serving the Lord in their own way.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Pariksit was such a Mahabhagavata devotee because he was initiated by a Mahabhagavata devotee, Shukadeva Swami.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Pariksit Maharaj became a Mahabhagavata due to being initiated by Sukadeva Goswami, and emphasizes that while impersonalists can become devotees, devotees never become impersonalists, highlighting the superiority of devotional service.

segments.key_quote: Even the verse says Those who are attached to is avyakta impersonal aspect of the absolute truth. For them there is so much of difficulty on the path of impersonal realization that they have to undergo.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes the Bhagavad Gita to illustrate that those attached to the impersonal aspect of the Absolute Truth face more suffering, reinforcing the idea that impersonal realization is an intermediate stage and that devotional service is the ultimate goal.

segments.key_quote: Therefore knowledge imparted by Sukhadeva Goswami unto Maharaj Pariksit helped him attain the service of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that the knowledge imparted by Sukadeva Goswami through the Srimad Bhagavatam helped Pariksit Maharaj attain the transcendental service of the Lord, which is the perfect stage of liberation, and ends with a thank you and Hare Krishna.
